0.user_question: Find the quotient when $x^9 + 1$ is divided by $x - 1.$

ost_step.1: Using polynomial long division or synthetic division, we set up the problem as follows:

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. To perform polynomial long division, we start dividing the highest degree terms first. Dividing $x^9$ by $x$, we get $x^8$. Multiplying $x - 1$ by $x^8$ yields $x^9 - x^8$. Subtracting this product from our original dividend results in $(x^9+1) - (x^9-x^8) = x^8+1$. Now we repeat the process using $x^8+1$ as the new dividend. Again, dividing the highest degree terms ($x^8$) by $x$, we obtain $x^7$. After multiplying and subtracting again, we continue until every power of $x$ has been reduced. By following this method through all nine divisions, what remains once we reach constant terms indicates the value of the quotient plus any possible remainder over $x - 1$. 1.subquestion: Which term should appear as part of our quotient initially during polynomial long division if considering only positive integer exponents starting at zero (the constant)?

subanswer.text: Considering the highest power terms, since \(x^9\) divided by \(x\) would yield \(x^8\), so the initial term of the quotient including the constant term (\(c_0 = c_{quotient}\)) will simply be \(\boxed{x^{9}}\). The answer is \(x^{9}\).
